The sites of McCoy Hall and
Levering Hall will soon be sold
at private sale to the highest bidder. This is an extraordinary opportunity for the Baltimore City
College to expand.
The entire block adjoining the
City College on the north between
Howard, Eutaw and Druid Hill
avenue, is now available for the
use of the City College if the City
will consider taking it over from
the Johns Hopkins University.
No money would be required ne:
cessarily, since the University
would probably be willing to take
City Stock in payment; or, if the
City desires to purchase the property out of the general budget,
the University would probably accept one-fourth the exact amount
per year for a period of four
years, meanwhile, occupying without rent the Chemical Laboratory
and Biological Laboratory. The
City College, each year in the last
four, has practically required an
additional floor in the old Main
Building located in the block 'offered and is now occupying the
entire building as an Annex. This
growth will continue, as surely as
the City is growing, and should
now be provided for. Men of vision who urge taking over this
Property before it is sold elsewhere will unquestionably do the
City College and the City a genuine service.
If this block is acquired by the
City, the building there will serve
the immediate needs of the City
College and in the future the
appearance and utility of the City
College may be substantially added to. In the first place, the
-architect who planned the City
College Building, evidently expected the buildings in front of it
to be razed or the street to be cut
through and, with that expectation in view, he put the entrance
around in what is now an alley.
This situation can be appreciated,
especially if one stands in front
of the main entrance of the City
College and looks at the building
from :that point of view. If this
situation is gtraiglitened out, it
will add tremendously to the value
of the College as a public building.
This block, in addition to affording an open space in front of
the City College, would also provide ample room for a Cage and
Annex over near the Eutaw street
side while the space immediately

Dr. Jos. T. Singewald, Jr.,* has
been granted A leave of absence
in order to carry on further geological investigations • in South
America. He will sail from New
Orleans on December 17. . .
The field of work will be in
northwestern Peru, and will consist primarily in an investigation
of the oil districts of that region,
and of the possibility of their extension. Although the work is
being done for one of the large
oil companies, it will afford an
opportunity to extend the geologic
investigations of the recent Williams Memorial Expedition.
The Williams Expedition was
prevented from entering this region on account of yellow fever
and the bubonic plague at the
port of entry'at Paita, Peru; hence
Dr. Singewald was unable to secure the geologic data on that
region. This work is expected to
yield additional material for the
collection of the Department of
Geology covering South America
and to form the basis of further
geologic and paleontologic researches by members of the department.
